Z ˜ 21 = { 1 ; 0 ; 1 } Orange 1.26 7.72% 31,246 Fixed setpoint strategy Fixed setpoint strategy according to guidelines (23 ± 1 °C, 50% ± 5%) Green 0.68 6.94% 9,120 single − LM Single-objective solution optimizing L M Gray 1.37 16.43% 37,044 single − PP D ∗ Single-objective solution optimizing P P D ∗ Yellow 0.81 5.00% 10,949 single − E tot Single-objective solution optimizing E t o t Purple 0.59 7.05% 2,513 Multi-objective optimization of HVAC control in museum environment for artwork preservation, visitors’ thermal comfort and energy efficiency Eva Schito ∗ Paolo Conti Luca Urbanucci Daniele Testi Department of Energy, Systems, Territory and Construction Engineering (DESTEC), University of Pisa, Italy Department of Energy, Systems Territory and Construction Engineering (DESTEC) University of Pisa Italy Department of Energy, Systems, Territory and Construction Engineering (DESTEC), University of Pisa, Italy ∗ Corresponding author. Largo L. Lazzarino, 2, 56122, Pisa, Italy. Largo L. Lazzarino, 2 Pisa 56122 Italy The paper deals with the multi-objective optimization of the HVAC control in museums. Scientific literature, technical standards and museums stakeholders mainly focus on the single-objective of artefacts conservation. However, a major attention should be paid at visitors’ comfort and energy consumption, without compromizing artwork integrity. In this work, we propose and apply a methodology to find the best control of the air-handling unit to concurrently optimize the three objectives. The proposed methodology is based on the achievement function method and finds the Pareto-optimal value of the HVAC control variables over the operational period. The priority given to each objective can be customized by changing the reference point of the achievement function. The method is applied to a museum in Italy hosting paper artworks during summer. Both exhibition room and HVAC system are simulated through an in-house dynamic model. The results show that all three objectives are improved with respect to typical fixed setpoint values (i.e., T = 23 °C and RH = 50%). Depending on the reference point, different profiles of indoor hygrothermal parameters are found; in any case, improvements of each of the objective functions indexes (equivalent lifetime multiplier for artwork preservation, predicted percentage of dissatisfied, and energy consumption) are obtained with respect to fixed setpoint strategy. The multi-objective optimization of museums with paper artworks in summer periods encourages low indoor temperatures. This would lead to slightly increased energy consumptions, which can be limited, by reducing the ventilation rate to 3–3.5 1/h instead of the typical 4–5 1/h. average value ~ reference point ˆ optimal value ∗ related to museum opening hours i d ideal point n a d nadir point 1 Introduction The maintenance of specific temperature and relative humidity setpoints in museums is necessary for the preservation of the exposed or stored artworks. Several researches have highlighted that inadequate microclimate values can lead to different types of deterioration, such as embrittlement, fading, and growth of microbial colonies and mold [1,2]. Thus, optimal ranges of temperature, T , and relative humidity, R H , are sought to minimize risks for artwork preservation, considering that each material is differently altered by microclimatic values and their variations [3–5]. The role of HVAC systems is therefore essential to guarantee the desired T and R H in these environments. Usually, the importance given to artwork preservation is so high that little attention has been given to the related requirements for the HVAC system. To meet the required environmental conditions, huge amounts of energy for heating, cooling, humidification and dehumidification are needed every day in all the zones where artworks are exposed or stored. Besides, in museums hosted in historic buildings, the design of HVAC system is also subject to restrictions, to preserve the intactness of the original structure, which is listed and considered of historic or cultural interest [6]. As a result, in these museums, HVAC systems often work in suboptimal conditions, requiring a high amount of energy for their operation. Only recently, after the implementation of European Directives [7,8], energy efficiency has been recognized as an important aspect to be combined to artwork preservation. However, the identification and application of both typical and innovative techniques [9] for reduction of energy requirements is not simple for this category of buildings, as some retrofit actions are not allowed in case of listed museums and because the artwork conservation is the priority. In their review [10], Sharif-Askari and Abu-Hijleh point out that the implementation of renewable energy systems in those historical buildings poses many problems due to visual impact and unicity of the envelope; in these particular environments, it is even more difficult to identify the most adequate solutions to both maintain correct microclimate and improve energy efficiency. Literature evidences that another aspect that needs a higher attention is visitors’ satisfaction during the museum experience: among the various parameters that are responsible for an appreciated visit, one is thermal comfort and it is linked to microclimate inside the building [11]. However, the need of thermal comfort is usually overcome by the requirements for a suitable environment for artworks [12] and a major attention on this topic is desirable. Thus, in museum environments, HVAC systems should ensure artwork integrity and visitors' comfort with the highest energy efficiency. This multi-objective problem has been tackled, in some cases (see for example [13]), with the identification of the main parameters affecting each objective at both building and HVAC level. This approach is useful to identify the most effective interventions to improve heritage preservation, visitors' comfort, and energy savings, but it could be unfeasible in an existing museum without relevant requalification works. The changing of the control subsystem parameters could represent a valid and more cost-effective action, to improve the desired objectives even in “protected” buildings [14], such as museums hosted in historic urban contexts. Improving control systems, in fact, does not cause any impact on the building. Some works, in literature, present the application on this multi-objective problem using efficient control strategies. In [15], the authors present the results of a monitoring period in a museum in Antwerp (Belgium): the analysis of the current indoor microclimate underlines that, during winter, T and R H need a stricter control to reduce risks for exhibits, whereas summer indoor hygrothermal profiles are good for both artworks and visitors' thermal comfort. Ferdyn-Grygierek and Grygierek [6] compare five different strategies in terms of T , R H and ventilation control in a Polish museum, aiming at finding the one that would lead to a reduction of R H fluctuations during the day in summer. The identified control strategy maintains a more adequate environment for artworks, strongly reducing the high daily fluctuations; besides, it does not need the installation of humidifiers or dehumidifiers, which is not possible in the analyzed museum, but uses the already installed system, consisting of radiators and mechanical ventilation. Some strategies involving the control system are also presented in [16], where the authors verify the energy savings obtained through the use of demand control ventilation and application of different T and R H setpoints. Also, simply varying the temperature setpoint among the seasons allows for an energy saving up to 13%. Kramer et al. [17] propose an algorithm for the identification of T and R H setpoints that guarantee collection preservation and thermal comfort for visitors. This algorithm results in a reduction of energy requirements up to 75%, if no changes on the envelope are concurrently carried out. In [18], the authors carry out a multi-objective optimization to find out the most adequate T and R H setpoints to be set in a museum HVAC system to improve energy efficiency, visitors’ comfort, and artwork lifespan. Furthermore, the optimal setpoints have been compared with traditionally used setpoints, showing that an improvement of all the three objectives is possible. Even if the application of multi-objective analysis is a widespread technique in the building sector (an extensive review of the various methodologies and indicators employed in recent scientific literature on this topic is found in [19]), its application in museums hosted in historical buildings needs further development. Nevertheless, the application of multi-objective optimization methods would help stakeholders and curators in operating HVAC systems in the most adequate way to meet the required targets. The present research seeks a strategy for the concurrent improving of energy efficiency, human thermal comfort, and artwork preservation in historic museums using a consistent and straightforward multi-objective optimization methodology (i.e., the achievement function approach). Differently from the other researches presented in this Introduction, the methodology presented in this work optimizes the control profiles of the HVAC system (e.g., supply temperature, humidity, and ventilation rate) at shorter timescales (hourly-or-less time step), to investigate advantages with respect to fixed-setpoints strategies or scenarios. The profiles of control variables are thus optimized according to the fast variation of internal heat gains (i.e., visitors’ entrance) and external climate. Furthermore, the methodology and resulting control profiles can be customized according to the importance given to each objective by museum owners or curators. In Section 2, the models for the simulation of the building and of the HVAC system are presented. Section 3 defines and describes the chosen indicators for the three objectives, and Section 4 discusses the optimization problem, illustrating the involved variables and constraints. Then, a case study is presented in Section 5, to highlight the handiness and usefulness of the procedure in a real application. 2 Building and HVAC simulation models This work is based on the so-called simulation-based optimization approach: the optimization algorithm employs a physical model of the building and HVAC system to compute the value of the objective functions at each iteration, finding their best values [20]. In this Section, we present the physical models used for the dynamic simulation of the museum environment, the air-handling unit, and the heat pump system used as both heating and cooling generator. The optimization strategy will be presented in Section 4. The building and equipment models allow the evaluation of the indoor temperature and humidity profiles, together with the assessment of the three indexes chosen as objective functions: - equivalent lifetime multiplier, e L M , as indicator for artwork preservation: it is defined in [21,22] and represents the variation in lifetime of an artwork due to the microclimate that is subjected to; thus, it should be equal to 1 (or higher); - predicted percentage of dissatisfied, P P D , as indicator for human thermal comfort: it is defined in [23] as the number of people that feel dissatisfied with the indoor environment, so this indicator should tend at the lowest possible value (according to the model, the minimum value is 5%); - total electrical energy consumption, E t o t , as indicator for energy efficiency, simply defined as the total energy needs at the HVAC system, so it should tend to zero. This indicator has been already used in [18]. These indicators are presented in Section 3. 2.1 The building The dynamic model of the building consists of a classical resistance-capacitance thermal network. The general expression of the energy balance of each node simply reads: (1) ρ c V d T d t = ∑ m ˙ i n h i n − ∑ m ˙ o u t h o u t + ∑ Q ˙ where T is the temperature of the node, m ˙ i n / o u t h i n / o u t are the inlet/outlet enthalpy fluxes, Q ˙ are heat transfer and generation occurring in the node. The possible types of node and the corresponding terms considered in Eq. (1) are shown in Table 1 . Shortly, the equivalent building network includes: one non-capacitive node, representing the internal surface of walls, ceilings and floors; one non-capacitive node, representing the outer surface of walls and roofs; one or more capacitive nodes for each homogeneous layer of walls, ceilings, and floors; two non-capacitive nodes at the inner and outer external glazer surfaces; one capacity node for the zone air temperature. For each zone, we refer to the number of nodes/temperatures to be evaluated as N s + 1 , being the last one the indoor air node/temperature. The overall set of energy balance equations can be discretized forming a linear ( N s + 1 ) × ( N s + 1 ) system, which is solved at each time step, to evaluate the dynamic state of the system as a function of the outdoor temperature and humidity, solar irradiation, visitors’ presence, artificial lighting, heat gains, supply flow rate, temperature and humidity by the air-handling unit. The validation of the building thermal model with reference to the established software TRNSYS 17 [24] is presented in the Case Study section. The other state variable related to the indoor environment is the humidity ratio, x a . Its evolution is evaluated according to the following mass balance: (2) K ρ a V a d x a d t = m ˙ s u p ( x s u p − x a ) + m ˙ i n f ( x i n f − x a ) + G ˙ where m ˙ s u p and m ˙ i n f are the supply and infiltration flow rates, respectively; G ˙ is the moisture production due to the visitors, and K is the effective moisture capacitance factor of the room [18,25]. 2.1.1 Sensible and latent gains due to the visitors The presence of visitors inside the rooms influences the profile of indoor temperature and relative humidity, due to the sensible and latent gains correlated to their activity. A value of 90 W for sensible gains and 95 W for latent gains are used for people standing or slowly walking, which are typical activities of museum visitors [23,24]. The convective fraction of the internal gains is 0.40; this value is taken from [26]. To determine the presence of visitors inside a room, we have used the model presented in [27], which is based on the knowledge of profiles of sold tickets at the box office and average lap times between the box office and the analyzed room. 2.2 Air-handling unit The air-handling unit delivers the air conditioning flow rate to the internal air node (see Table 1), influencing the thermo-hygrometric evolution of the building. The general layout of the device is shown in Fig. 1 . It includes a surface recovery heat exchanger (i.e. economizer), a recovery air-mixing plenum, a heating and a cooling coil, a steam vaporizer, and supply and extraction fans. The energy input required to run the AHU ( Q ˙ A H U , C , Q ˙ A H U , H , W ˙ A H U , v a p ) are evaluated through the mass and the energy balance of each component, according to the respective constitutive equation and performance parameters [28]. The AHU set of equations are summarized in Table 2 . As for the electrical input of the system, it includes the energy required to run the air-circulation fans and the energy required to the operation of the heat pump. The former quantity is evaluated as a function of the nominal power disclosed by the AHU manufacturer, according to the typical hydraulic relationship between power and flow rate: (3) W ˙ f a n , i n = W ˙ f a n , r e f ( m ˙ s u p m ˙ s u p , r e f ) 3 2.3 The generator: multi-purpose heat pump The thermal quantities Q ˙ A H U , C and Q ˙ A H U , H are delivered by a multi-purpose heat pump. Considering the double useful effect and the immediate equivalence C O P H = C O P C + 1 , we arbitrary choose C O P C as the reference coefficient of performance for the device. The heat pump energy balance is evaluated according to the following algorithm: the available heat power at the condenser, Q ˙ C O N D , is a function of C O P C and of the thermal demand of the cooling/dehumidifier coil, Q ˙ A H U , C . If Q ˙ C O N D is greater than the thermal demand at the AHU heating coil Q ˙ A H U , H , the excess of heat, Q ˙ C O N D − Q ˙ A H U , H , is rejected to the external air through an additional heat exchanger (see Fig. 2 ). Otherwise, if Q ˙ C O N D < Q ˙ A H U , H , the required heat power at the evaporator, Q ˙ E V A , is evaluated as a function of C O P C and of the thermal demand of the heating coil, namely we have Q ˙ C O N D = Q ˙ A H U , H and Q ˙ E V A = Q ˙ A H U , H ( C O P C C O P C + 1 ) . The additional quantity Q ˙ E V A − Q ˙ A H U , C requested for the evaporation process is provided by a back-up air heat exchanger (see again Fig. 2). For each objective function, an indicator is presented. 3.1 Artwork integrity indicator The assessment of possible risks for artworks is achievable through the analysis of typical degradation mechanisms due to temperature and relative humidity. These mechanisms have been studied in the last decades and some correlations or typical values to be maintained have been proposed to lessen risks. For the majority of artworks, three mechanisms have been identified as the most dangerous: - Biological damage, due to too high relative humidity values, leading to spore germination and mold formation; - Mechanical damage, due to too large cycles of relative humidity on short periods (e.g., daily period), leading to shifts between layers and cracks; - Chemical damage, due to deterioration mechanisms (e.g., acid hydrolysis) occurring for unsuitable values of temperature and relative humidity, inducing paper embrittlement and generally modifying the mechanical properties of the materials made of cellulose [29]. In museums, HVAC systems are usually present, so too high values of RH (responsible for biological damage) or too high variation of T and/or RH (responsible for mechanical damage) are unlikely to happen. Thus, in museums with HVAC systems, the inappropriate choice of T and/or RH setpoints could lead to chemical damage risk, reducing artwork lifetime. Chemical damage is assessed through an indicator: the equivalent lifetime multiplier, e L M , which compares the effects of given climatic parameters with a reference microclimate (i.e. 20 °C and 50%). The results of the comparison represent the ratio between the predicted lifetime of the artwork subjected to the real climate and the typical lifetime for artworks (e.g., for paper artworks, 500 years [30]): it is then crucial that this value is at least equal to 1. At time t , where the values of temperature and relative humidity in the museum room are T t and R H t , the equations read: (5a) L M t = ( R H r e f R H t ) 1.3 exp [ E a R ( 1 T t + 273.15 − 1 T r e f ) ] (5b) e L M = 1 1 N ∑ t = 1 N ( 1 L M t ) where T r e f = 293.15 K and R H r e f = 50 % (reference climate for comparison), R is the ideal gas constant equal to 8.314 J/(mol K), E a is the activation energy, in J/mol, depending on artwork type (e.g., 100 kJ/mol for paper, 70 kJ/mol for varnish [31], 60 kJ/mol for frescoes [32]), and N is the total number of analyzed time periods. The model is presented in detail in [31,33]. The equation for the evaluation of e L M represents a weighted mean of the single L M values, where periods resulting in a L M lower than 1 have a higher effect in the overall indicator. 3.2 Visitors’ thermal comfort indicator Several mechanisms influence the sensation of thermal comfort, depending on the air temperature, radiant temperature, relative humidity, and air velocity visitors are subject to. Usually, the model used to predict human thermal comfort in conditioned rooms is the one developed by Fanger [34], which considers six variables influencing human comfort: the previously mentioned four parameters, metabolic activity, and clothing insulation level. The application of Fanger's method allows the evaluation of two indicators: the predicted mean vote, P M V , and the predicted percentage of dissatisfied, P P D . The P M V indicator suggests a mean vote for the environment, being −3 “too cold” and +3 “too hot”, so a 0 vote is correlated to an ideal comfortable space. The P P D indicator shows a percentage of people that feel uncomfortable in the indoor space (because of one of the two extreme sensations). More details on this method and typical values for metabolic activity and clothing insulation level can be found in [23]. P P D indicator is used in this work to assess visitors' thermal comfort, where a value near 5% means optimal comfort (5% is the minimum value for this indicator, according to Fanger's model [23]). In this work, we refer to P P D ∗ ‾ , namely the average value of the percentage of dissatisfied during the opening hours of the museum. 3.3 Energy efficiency indicator Considering the generic system discussed in Section 2.1, a simple indicator for the energy efficiency is the total electrical energy required by the HVAC system, which can be evaluated through the sum of two terms: the electrical energy needed at the heat pump E H P , i n , and the electrical energy needed for the AHU fans, E f a n , i n . (6) E t , t o t = E t , H P , i n + E t , f a n , i n where E t simply corresponds to the product between the electrical power W ˙ t and time-step duration. In this context, the energy indicator should be as low as possible, to maximize the energy efficiency of the system. 4 Multi-objective optimization methodology Multi-objective optimization problems generally have many suitable solutions, corresponding to the so-called Pareto front, i.e. the set of the Pareto-optimal solutions in the vector space of the objective functions. The aim of multi-objective optimization methods is to identify one or more solutions on the Pareto front, according to a given criterion. Fig. 3 shows an illustrative example of Pareto front for a minimization problem with two objective functions, together with the ideal and nadir points. The ideal and nadir points consist of the lower and upper bounds of the Pareto front, respectively. They can be identified by optimizing each objective individually. Additionally, the ideal and nadir points are generally used to normalize the objectives over the Pareto front, to properly compare the objectives (see Eq. (7)): (7) Z ‾ ‾ i = ( Z i ( x ) − Z i i d ) / ( Z i n a d − Z i i d ) To identify Pareto optimal solutions, tailored optimization techniques are needed, to avoid unfeasible exhaustive searches. Some optimization techniques are intrinsically suitable for multi-objective optimization, such as population-based metaheuristic algorithms (e.g., Genetic Algorithm and Particle Swarm Optimization). However, these methods do not guarantee the Pareto-optimality of the solutions, because of their metaheuristic nature. The use of “exact” single-objective optimization methods would be preferable, but this requires the so-called “scalarization” of the objective functions. Scalarization consists in converting the multi-objective problem into several single-objective optimization problems (one for each sought Pareto-optimal solution) via a scalar objective function, which is called scalarizing function. This enables the adoption of single-objective optimization algorithms that can guarantee the Pareto-optimality of the found solution. In this work, the achievement function approach is adopted as scalarizing method, which guarantees the Pareto-optimality of all the solutions and can find any Pareto-optimal solution, even if the problem is non-convex [35]. The following achievement function is adopted: (8) s ( x , Z ˜ ) = max i = 1 , … , 3 ( Z ‾ ‾ i ( x ) − Z ˜ i ) + ξ ∑ i = 1 3 ( Z ‾ ‾ i ( x ) − Z ˜ i ) where s is the scalarizing function, ξ is a small augmentation coefficient ( ξ = 10 − 4 ), and Z ˜ is the so-called reference point, that corresponds to a vector of arbitrary aspiration levels for the three normalized objective functions, Z ˜ = { Z ˜ 1 , Z ˜ 2 , Z ˜ 3 } . The single-objective minimization of s ( x , Z ˜ ) corresponds to finding the Pareto point closest to the chosen reference point. In other words, Z ˜ coordinates guide the search of the optimization algorithm: a reference point close to a single-objective solution increases the priority given to that objective. Thanks to this approach, the decision maker can directly express one or more reference points, finding the corresponding Pareto-optimal solutions, and analyzing the differences between the Pareto-optimal alternatives. The search of Pareto-optimal solutions is thus a 4-step procedure: 1. To formulate and solve the three single-objective optimization problems; 2. To define ideal and nadir points and normalize the vector space formed by the three objective functions; 3. To define the reference points; 4. To formulate and solve the scalarized single-objective optimization problems, depending on the chosen reference points. In section 5.3, we will present the actual mathematical formulation of the just-mentioned steps for the considered case study. 5 Case study A case study has been selected to apply the discussed optimization methodology and verify the improvements with respect to a traditional fixed-setpoint control. The selected thermal zone is an exhibition room of a museum in Pisa, Italy, which hosts important temporary exhibitions every year. The simulation period goes from June 1st to September 30th (122 days) with a time step equal to 15 min. This time step has been chosen because people variation inside the room has been observed with this periodicity: as heat gains due to people are the main driving force influencing indoor microclimate, HVAC system should change its operational parameters with this frequency. Weather data concerning the typical meteorological year of outdoor temperature, humidity, and global solar radiation on the horizontal is provided by the Italian Thermotechnical Committee (CTI) in [36], with an hourly time step. External temperature and relative humidity can be immediately used as inputs, whereas Perez model has been considered to evaluate diffuse radiation starting from the global solar radiation on a horizontal surface. Some information about the external climate in Pisa is reported in Table 3 . The exhibition room is located within a historic building museum, built between the 16th and the 18th century, in the historic center of Pisa. The room has four external walls (roof included), no glazed area, and two internal walls adjacent to zones with the same indoor climate evolution; the floor area is about 100 m2. External walls and roofs have typical local structures: the wall stratigraphy is in bricks and rubble masonry filling; the roof is in clay tiles and wooden beams. The main characteristics of the chosen exhibition room (e.g., geometry, thermal characteristics, and other inputs used in the simulation) are reported in Table 4 . Section 5.1 shows the validation of the proposed building thermal network with respect to a validated TRNSYS model. The museum is open all days from 9:00 a.m. to 7:00 p.m. HVAC can be activated 24/7 according to the chosen control strategy. In this work, we used the same visitors’ occupancy profile presented in [27], according to a reference profile of sold tickets for the museum. The average presence is about 20 people per hour with two peaks in the morning and late afternoon (about 115 individuals). The air-handling unit serving the considered zone includes a cooling/dehumidifier coil, a steam vaporizer, a heating coil, and the supply fan. The bypass factor, the heat transfer effectiveness, and the other parameters are shown in Table 4. The generation unit consists of a multi-purpose heat pump (see Section 2.3), which provides both heating and cooling energy to the coils of the air-handling unit. The Second-Law efficiency of the device is shown in Table 4. Other details about the case study can be found in [18,37]. 5.1 Validation of the model The main characteristics of the considered exhibition room were set in the in-house model discussed in Section 2.1.1, with the aim of simulating the energy demand. First of all, we validated the model using a TRNSYS model reproducing the exhibition room and the HVAC system. TRNSYS was chosen as it is a well-known software for building and energy system dynamic simulation, and it is also often used in indoor museum simulation [38,39]. The TRNSYS model had been, in turn, validated through the results of a measurement campaign carried out during a past winter exhibition, during which the indoor environment and operational model of the HVAC system were accurately monitored. The experimental data and the reference validated TRNSYS model for the rooms have been presented in [37]. In this work, we used the same validated TRNSYS model to assess the accuracy of the in-house dynamic model for summer operation. Specifically, we simulated the ideal evolution of the sensible and latent demand profiles, when 23 °C and 50% are imposed in the air zone during the opening hours of the above-mentioned 122 days. The simulation time step is 15 min. Additionally, we analyzed the profile of the indoor humidity, mean radiant and air temperature. The deviation indexes between the results obtained through the in-house code and TRNSYS 17 are presented in Table 5 . The corresponding deviations in terms of sensible and latent energy demands over the whole simulation period are 89 kWh (2357 vs. 2446 kWh, −3.6%) and 32 kWh (2315 vs. 2282 kWh, 1%), respectively. All the deviation indexes prove the suitability of the in-house building model for the purposes of the present work. 5.2 Control variables According to the assumptions and the overall set of equations presented in Section 2, the state evolution of the building, air-handling unit, and heat pump generator can be calculated as a function of three discrete control variables forming the control vector x = { m ˙ s u p , T s u p , T A H U , R } , namely: - Supply flow rate, m ˙ s u p , in the discrete range: (9a) m ˙ s u p = 0,0.5 , 1 … 7.5 , 8 × ρ a V a 3600 k g / s - Supply air temperature, T s u p , in the discrete range: (9b) T s u p = { 16,17,18 … 25,26 } [ ° C ] - Dew point temperature of the dehumidification coil, T R , in the discrete range: (9c) T A H U , R = { 3,4,5 … 9,10 } [ ° C ] We seek the optimal sequence of the control vector x t corresponding to the optimal control of the air-handling unit. To do that, we assume that the problem under investigation is “static” [40], namely the thermo-hygrometric inertia of the room is negligible compared to the other terms of the energy balance. This is what happens in our case, due to the major relevance of heat gains related to the large number of visitors with respect to the thermo-hygrometric capacity of the air volume. Therefore, the “greedy” approach can be adopted, i.e. each time step can be solved independently, thus significantly reducing the size of the search space. An exhaustive-search technique is used to identify the optimal solution at each time step within the set of possible x values. 5.3 Optimization constraints At each time step, the control vector x t must fulfill some constraints related to the thermal comfort and indoor air quality within the exhibition room, namely: - Maximum value of P P D ∗ The predicted percentage of dissatisfied during the opening hours of the museum must not exceed 30% to preserve a minimum comfort level for visitors. Note that, in this case, a limit for P P D ∗ is applied to prevent instantaneous (not average) thermal discomfort. (10) P P D * ≤ 30 % - Minimum ventilation rate Similarly to the previous constraint, the ventilation rate must be coherent with typical level of indoor air quality presented in EN 16798–1:2019 [41]. (11) m ˙ e x t * ≥ m ˙ v e n t , m i n 5.4 Multi-objective optimization 5.4.1 Optimization step #1: the single-objective problems As presented in Section 4, the achievement function approach requires the definition of one or more reference points that guide the optimization search through the closest Pareto-optimal solution. The first step of the proposed multi-optimization procedure consists of solving three single-objective optimization problems, one for each i-th objective function. According to the “greedy” approach, each i-th problem reads: Process #1. Solution of the single-objective optimization problem. ∀ t , f i n d x ˆ t = { m ˙ ˆ t , s u p , T ˆ t , s u p , T ˆ t , A H U , R } which optimizes the i-th objective function Z t , i , subject to: P P D ∗ ( x t ) − 0.3 ≤ 0 m ˙ t , v e n t , m i n − m ˙ t , e x t ≤ 0 The optimization problem in Process #1 is solved for each time step and for each objective function, Z i . We recall that Z t , 1 = L M t should be maximized, while Z t , 2 = P P D t ∗ and Z t , 3 = E t , t o t should be minimized. The L M t is chosen as objective function according to the “static” assumption described in Section 5.2. In other words, maximizing the L M t value should ensure good values of e L M . The three single-objective optimization problems lead to the three single-objective optimal sequences of the control vectors x ˆ t , L M , x ˆ t , P P D ∗ , and x ˆ t , E t o t , together with the corresponding sequences of the objective functions Z t , L M , Z t , P P D ∗ , Z t , E t o t . The coordinates of the ideal point refer to the solutions of the single-objective problems, namely: (13a) Z t , i d = { L M ( x ˆ t , L M ) , P P D ( x ˆ t , P P D ∗ ) , E t o t ( x ˆ t , E t o t ) } (13b) Z t , n d r = { min [ L M ( x ˆ t , P P D ∗ ) , L M ( x ˆ t , E t o t ) ] , max [ P P D ∗ ( x ˆ t , L M ) , P P D ∗ ( x ˆ t , E t o t ) ] , max [ E t o t ( x ˆ t , L M ) , E t o t ( x ˆ t , P P D ∗ ) ] } The normalized vector of the objective functions is: (14a) Z ‾ ‾ t x t = Z ‾ ‾ t , 1 x t , Z ‾ ‾ t , 2 x t , Z ‾ ‾ t , 3 x t where (14b) Z ‾ ‾ t , 1 x t = Z 1 x t − Z t , n d r , 1 / Z t , i d , 1 − Z t , n d r , 1 (14c) Z ‾ ‾ t , 2 x t = Z 2 x t − Z t , n d r , 2 / Z t , i d , 2 − Z t , n d r , 2 (14d) Z ‾ ‾ t , 3 x t = Z 3 x t − Z t , n d r , 3 / Z t , i d , 3 − Z t , n d r , 3 In this work, the normalized coordinates of ideal and nadir points are Z ‾ ‾ t , i d = { 1,0,0 } and Z ‾ ‾ t , n d r = { 0,1,1 } (see Fig. 4 ). 5.4.3 Optimization step #3: definition of reference points The third step defines the reference points and the corresponding scalarizing functions. In this work, we explore the 3D Pareto front through 61 reference points (see Fig. 4), corresponding to a regular grid of pace 0.5 in the normalized axes range 0–1. Each reference point defines the j -th scalarizing function, s j ( x , Z ˜ j ) , and the corresponding scalarized problem to be solved at each time step t (see step #4). 5.4.4 Optimization step #4: scalarized single-objective optimization problems Finally, in the fourth step, the minimization of s t , j ( x t , Z ˜ j ) finds the optimal multi-objective control vector x ˆ t , which corresponds to the multi-objective Pareto-optimal control strategy. Process #2 is repeated for all considered reference points, Z ˜ j , finding an equal number of Pareto-optimal control strategies. Process #2. Minimization of the j-th achievement function. ∀ t , f i n d x ˆ t = { m ˙ ˆ t , s u p , T ˆ t , s u p , T ˆ t , A H U , R } which minimizes s t , j x t , Z ~ j = max i = 1,2,3 Z ‾ ‾ t , i − Z ~ i , j + ρ ∑ i = 1 3 Z ‾ ‾ t , i − Z ~ i , j subject to: P P D ∗ ( x t ) − 0.3 ≤ 0 m ˙ t , v e n t , m i n − m ˙ t , e x t ≤ 0 6 Discussions and results The multi-objective control strategies presented in Section 5.4 are compared with a typical fixed-setpoint control strategy, as presented in [4] for paper preservation. In other words, the air-handling unit tries to maintain an indoor temperature within the range of 23 ± 1 °C and a relative humidity equal to 50% ± 5%. For fixed-setpoint simulation-optimization scenario, the mathematical model of the exhibition room and HVAC system is the same one described in Section 2. The optimization-simulation algorithm finds the control vector x ˆ t = { m ˙ ˆ t , s u p , T ˆ t , s u p , T ˆ t , A H U , R } that maintain the indoor temperature and humidity as close as possible to the objective setpoints, with a maximum allowed deviation equal to the above-mentioned dead bands. In case of multiple solutions for x ˆ t , the algorithm chooses the one corresponding to the minimum ventilation rate. 6.1 Analysis of the results Fig. 5 shows the 61 points resulting from the multi-objective optimization according to the chosen reference points. The coordinates of all black points represent the integral values of the objective functions over the exhibition period (see Table 6 ). As general trend, we note that e L M and P P D ∗ ‾ do not coherently improve, as paper artwork conservation requires lower temperature than visitors’ comfort; e L M and E t o t , instead, have a coherent trend as more energy is required in summer for cooling and dehumidification. The pink squares, red triangles, and blue diamond represent the seasonal values of the single-objective optimizations of L M , P P D ∗ , and E t o t , respectively. The cyan star corresponds to the typical fixed-setpoint control strategy presented in Section 0. The seasonal values of performance indexes are shown in Tables 6 and 7 . As expected, the s i n g l e − L M requires a lot of energy to maximize the lifetime multiplier and does not ensure a sufficient comfort. The s i n g l e − E t o t strategy results in an acceptable P P D ∗ ‾ value, but it compromises artwork preservation, as well as s i n g l e − P P D ∗ . We note that fixed-setpoint solution has similar performance indexes of the s i n g l e − E t o t solution. It has a low energy consumption, but the corresponding e L M value can be improved, though it derives from a technical standard that is tailored for artwork preservation. We expect an e L M value close to the maximum value (around 1.25), instead the system acts as it was designed for energy savings. We now expand the analysis on two multi-objective points to show the benefits of the proposed approach. The fixed-setpoint control strategy is compared with strategy #1 and strategy #21. The first one is obtained using the ideal point as reference point; the second one may be associate to a typical approach of a museum curator, who generally privileges artwork preservation and visitors’ comfort. The ideal point has been chosen, as it gives the same relevance to all objective functions. Finally, we also show the results of the single-objective optimization to give a more exhaustive perspective of the deviation from ideal conditions. All the seasonal values of the analyzed control strategies are summarized in Table 7. Fig. 6 shows the evolution of the indoor temperature and relative humidity depending on considered control strategies. We note that the two multi-objective solutions ensure a low indoor temperature with values close to the ones obtained with the single-objective optimization of e L M . Relative humidity is always in the range 40%–55%, without relevant deviations among control solutions, apart from the s i n g l e − E t o t solution that does not seem to control temperature and humidity. Fig. 6-c shows the ventilation flow rate according to the control strategies, highlighting that those solutions mainly aimed at preserving artwork lifetime have the highest ventilation rate (i.e. ID #21 and ID s i n g l e − L M ). The fixed-setpoint strategy maintains the indoor temperature and humidity quite close to the selected setpoints. Fig. 7 shows an additional insight on the evolution of the indoor temperature, humidity, and ventilation rate, according to the analyzed control strategies. We plotted the typical-day profiles of each quantity as the most representative daily profile of each variable on a 15-min time step. The typical days have been chosen through a centroid-based clustering technique [42]: in other words, each profile in Fig. 7 belongs to the most representative day (i.e., the centroid) of the set (i.e., the clusters) containing all the 122 daily profiles of a given quantity. The centroid is the element with the minimum of the squared deviations from the other cluster members [42]. The analysis of the daily profiles confirm the conclusions obtained from Fig. 6. The control strategies aimed at optimizing the e L M objectives result in lower indoor temperatures and higher ventilation rates. The control strategy associated to the curator's point of view has higher air temperature during the opening hours of the museums because of the equal relevance given to visitors' comfort. On the contrary, s i n g l e − P P D ∗ and s i n g l e − E t o t have high air temperature during the day and even higher during night-time due to the free-floating behavior during these hours. The absence of air-conditioning is confirmed by subfigure (c), as pointed out by the nil yellow and purple series during nights. With reference to the humidity, all the control strategies produce similar profiles, with the only exception of the s i n g l e − E t o t strategy, which does not control indoor microclimate, but it only respects the constraints of the problem. The control strategy #1 (i.e., ideal point) is confirmed to be a trade-off for all quantities. Through the comparison of ventilation rate profiles (see Fig. 6) and energy requirement profiles (see Fig. 8 ), we note that the two variables are correlated, being the electrical input of air-circulation fans a relevant share of the required system energy. The profiles of the other two objectives, L M and P P D , are shown in Fig. 9 and Fig. 10 , respectively. As above-mentioned, control strategies with higher energy consumption and ventilation rates also have higher L M : strategies s i n g l e − L M , #21, and #1 have artwork preservation index always higher than one, while the other three strategies do not ensure a good preservation. Strategy #1 is in the middle for all the performance indexes and state variables, as it slightly reduces artwork preservation to save energy. The concurrent analysis of Figs. 6 and 8 confirms the need of low indoor temperature and higher ventilation rates to have high artwork conservation index, at the cost of higher energy requirements. Also, the profiles of P P D (see Fig. 10) are quite similar and lower than 10% for all control strategies, apart for s i n g l e − L M solution that results in too low indoor air temperature. Multi-objective control solutions are the only ones with an average P P D lower than 10% and an average L M higher than 1. We also note that fixed-setpoint strategy acts similarly to the s i n g l e − P P D ∗ solution, with good comfort values but unsatisfactory L M . As expected, then, strategy #1 is the best tradeoff between all objective functions, with lower P P D ∗ than strategy #21, despite a lower e L M . Strategy #21 shows instead the conflicting requirements of energy and artworks, with a particularly high value of ventilation rate. Fig. 11 shows the distribution of the L M , P P D * , and ventilation rate over the simulation period. The m ˙ s u p value has been chosen as representative of energy efficiency, due to its high correlation with power input. We note that the distributions of all indexes for all control strategies have a small deviation with respect to the average value, with only exceptions of the ventilation rate for s i n g l e − P P D ∗ , s i n g l e − E t o t , and fixed setpoints strategies. We can conclude that the optimal multi-objective control strategies are characterized by quite constant profiles of state and control variables. This feature is relevant in terms of practical implementation as it facilitates the operation of actuators. The three exceptions concern the ventilation rate: s i n g l e − P P D * does not ventilate during the closing hours of the museum, as it considers thermal comfort only when visitors are present, in other words, m ˙ s u p is null during nighttime to save energy; s i n g l e − E t o t oscillates between zero and the minimum air flow rate (see m ˙ v e n t , m i n in Eq. (11)), to meet the constraint only during opening hours; fixed setpoints strategy varies m ˙ s u p to maintain the indoor temperature and humidity as close as possible to the setpoint values. 7 Conclusions The paper has presented a multi-objective optimization method for HVAC control in museum environments. All the three main objective functions are considered: artwork preservation, visitors’ thermal comfort, and energy consumption. The proposed methodology is based on the achievement function approach and allows the identification of the Pareto-optimal control strategy at each time, depending on a chosen reference point. By testing more reference points, one can explore different seasonal performances as a function of the relevance given to each objective. In this work, we simulated and optimized the quarter-of-hour control of an air-handling unit coupled to a multi-purpose heat pump system, serving an exhibition room located in Pisa (Italy) during a summer exposition of paper artworks. We found 61 multi-objective optimal control strategies. We compared a selection of two of them with a classical control strategy based on a fixed temperature and humidity setpoints. The main findings resulting from the presented case study are coherent at all the time scales (i.e., 15-min boxplots, typical-day and daily average profiles) and hereby summarized: • The proposed multi-objective optimization procedure finds the multi-objective optimal profiles of HVAC control variables, according to the priority given to each objective (i.e. the reference point) by curators, HVAC operators, or other museum stakeholders; • In general, e L M and P P D ∗ ‾ are conflicting objectives in summer periods as paper artwork preservation requires low indoor temperatures that result in discomfort for visitors in summer clothing. On the contrary, P P D ∗ and E t o t are coherent objectives, as both take advantage from indoor mild temperatures. • e L M maximization increases energy consumption, as it requires low indoor temperature and high ventilation rates to be maintained in summer season; • Fixed-setpoint strategy results in suboptimal performance indexes. Despite the lower energy consumption and good P P D ∗ ‾ values, the e L M value can be notably improved, though analyzed setpoint values derive from a technical standard aimed at artwork preservation; • Among the others, we analyzed the control strategy using the ideal point as reference point, in other words the one with equal relevance given to all the three objectives. The resulting index values are: e L M = 1.12 , P P D ∗ ‾ = 8.17 % , E n t o t = 12,352 k W h . The distribution of the ventilation rate is about 3–3.5 vol per hour, which is lower than typical ventilation rate for museum environments and more constant than that required by fixed setpoints strategy. • We also analyzed a solution corresponding to a typical curator's point of view, which favorites the artwork preservation and visitors' comfort. The resulting performance indexes are: e L M = 1.26 , P P D ∗ ‾ = 7.72 % , E t o t = 31,246 k W h . The found ventilation rates are very high (7–8 vol per hour) as it is mainly tailored for artwork preservation, but do not pay a sufficient attention to energy savings. Indeed, during the nighttime, when there are no constraints in terms of P P D value, the air flow rate is maximized to lower the indoor temperature and increase the average e L M . Future works will analyze the HVAC system behavior also in winter, where the concurrent optimization of the three objective functions and the difference in the external climate conditions can result in different profiles of HVAC control settings. Furthermore, possible future remarks will deal with the practical implementation of the found optimal multi-objective control strategies in HVAC controllers and actuators in real museums. In particular, it would be interesting to check the operation of this actuator considering the stochastic evolution of weather conditions and visitors’ presence: at the moment, in fact, the ideal knowledge of external climate and people presence represents an input of the model. coredata.dc:description: The paper deals with the multi-objective optimization of the HVAC control in museums. Scientific literature, technical standards and museums stakeholders mainly focus on the single-objective of artefacts conservation. However, a major attention should be paid at visitors’ comfort and energy consumption, without compromizing artwork integrity. In this work, we propose and apply a methodology to find the best control of the air-handling unit to concurrently optimize the three objectives. The proposed methodology is based on the achievement function method and finds the Pareto-optimal value of the HVAC control variables over the operational period. The priority given to each objective can be customized by changing the reference point of the achievement function. The method is applied to a museum in Italy hosting paper artworks during summer. Both exhibition room and HVAC system are simulated through an in-house dynamic model. The results show that all three objectives are improved with respect to typical fixed setpoint values (i.e., T = 23 °C and RH = 50%). Depending on the reference point, different profiles of indoor hygrothermal parameters are found; in any case, improvements of each of the objective functions indexes (equivalent lifetime multiplier for artwork preservation, predicted percentage of dissatisfied, and energy consumption) are obtained with respect to fixed setpoint strategy. The multi-objective optimization of museums with paper artworks in summer periods encourages low indoor temperatures. This would lead to slightly increased energy consumptions, which can be limited, by reducing the ventilation rate to 3–3.5 1/h instead of the typical 4–5 1/h.
coredata.dc:title: Multi-objective optimization of HVAC control in museum environment for artwork preservation, visitors’ thermal comfort and energy efficiency
